deployments package¶

Provides the ability to manage a Deployment. In essence, the physical building at which eGenie is deployed. This includes the physical address, a picture of the location, the hub which is present in the building to collect data, and additional data (such as energy costs and extra notes).

A Deployment has one of four states: Incomplete (not yet ready to be put ‘live’); Not Running; Running; and Ended. Once a Deployment is ended, an ‘end date’ is stored in its DeploymentState so the correct readings are returned at any given time. If a sensor is restarted, previous readings are cleared.

See also

SensorDeploymentDetails

deployments.models module¶

class deployments.models.Deployment(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django_extensions.db.models.TimeStampedModel

Records information about a deployment. While the hub might not be permanent (if it gets reassigned to another deployment) the sensor readings are permanent to this deployment via SensorDeploymentDetails.

exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

address_line_one¶

The first line of the deployment’s physical address.

client_name¶

The client name: might be a home owner’s name (Mrs Jones), or a company name (ABC Ltd), for example.

deployment_states¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

deploymentannotation_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

elec_pence_per_kwh¶

How much electricity costs per KWh in the location.

end()[source]¶

End this deployment. The end_date is set to the current date and time, any sensors that are active in the deployment are deactivated, and the hub is cleared for use in other deployments.

gas_pence_per_kwh¶

How much gas costs per KWh in the location.

get_next_by_created(*moreargs, **morekwargs)¶
get_next_by_modified(*moreargs, **morekwargs)¶
get_previous_by_created(*moreargs, **morekwargs)¶
get_previous_by_modified(*moreargs, **morekwargs)¶
hub¶

The hub that has been deployed at the site. This is optional until the deployment needs to be started.

hub_id¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

id¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

notes¶

Any notes that go along with the deployment.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>¶
pairs¶

A set of sensor/channel pairs associated with this deployment. e.g. temperature_1 / temperature.

Warning

Check that this is actually used.

photo¶

A photo to represent the deployment - might be a picture of a room or a building.

plinth_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

post_code¶

The deployment’s postcode.

running¶

True if the deployment is running (i.e. does not have end_date set), False otherwise.

sensor_details¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

start()[source]¶

Start the deployment if not already running. Creates a new DeploymentState, and clears any existing sensor readings. Raises a ValueError if the Deployment is running already.

status¶

Returns the current status of the deployment. Options are: (1, ‘Details Incomplete’) (2, ‘Deployment not running’) (3, ‘Deployment Running’) (4, ‘Deployment Ended’)

class deployments.models.DeploymentState(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django_extensions.db.models.TimeStampedModel

Records when a deployment started and when it ended. The start date is found via the built-in created field (i.e. when the DeploymentState was created).

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

deployment¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

deployment_id¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

end_date¶

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.
